facts.text: Suit instituted on February 10, 1950 in the District Court of Kottayam.
Suit transferred to the Court of the Subordinate Judge, Meenachil sometime in the year 1956.
Suit substantially decreed in appellant's favour on July 30, 1958.
Appeal preferred by first defendant Tirumala Gounder against the decree.
Appeal preferred in January 1959 by H.B. Mohammad Rowther, 8th defendant.
Appellant preferred an appeal against the part of the decree adverse to him.
All three appeals heard together and disposed of by common judgment on August 10, 1960 by single Judge of Kerala High Court; appeals by defendants 1 and 8 allowed, appellant's appeal dismissed.
Suit and appeals valued at Rs. 3,000.

Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E. (corresponding to 1949 A.D.) in force at time suit instituted; under s.20 read with s.21, appeals valued over Rs. 1,000 to be heard by Division Bench of two Judges.
Said Act repealed by Kerala High Court Act, 1958 (Act No. 5 of 1959), assent of President on February 6, 1959, came into force on March 3, 1959.
Under s.5 of Kerala High Court Act 5 of 1959, jurisdiction of single Judge extended to appeals from original decree where value did not exceed Rs. 10,000.
Appeals placed for hearing before single Judge, overruling appellant's plea that they should be heard only by Division Bench.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave from Kerala High Court judgment.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appeals could be heard and disposed of by a single Judge of the High Court.

Whether the right to have appeals heard by a Division Bench under the Travancore-Cochin High Court Act vested upon institution of suit or filing of appeals and could not be taken away by the Kerala High Court Act implicitly.
Whether hearing by single Judge affected the right of appeal to Supreme Court under Article 133.

petitioner_arguments.text: Right to have appeals heard by Division Bench conferred by Travancore-Cochin High Court Act, in force when suit and appeals filed, not taken away expressly by Kerala Act 5 of 1959 and could not be taken away by implication.
Right of appeal is substantive vested right existing from date of institution of suit, governed by law at that date, can only be taken away expressly or by necessary intendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Garikapati Veerara v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury, 1957 S.C.R. 488

petitioner_arguments.text: Depriving right to Division Bench affected further right of appeal to Supreme Court under Art. 133, which vested at institution of suit.
One contesting respondent, being in pari delicto with plaintiff, ought not to have been permitted to raise question as to maintainability of suit.

court_reasoning.text: Only question of law is whether appeals could be heard by single Judge; other questions are pure questions of fact; no grave errors in fact findings, so no interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Article 133 cl.3 bars appeal to SC from single Judge unless Parliament provides otherwise; settled practice not to interfere with HC fact findings absent grave errors.

court_reasoning.text: Right to prefer appeal from first instance court under s.96 CPC; which bench hears is procedural matter, no vested right to specified number of judges.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Travancore-Cochin HC Act dealt with procedural matters like jurisdiction of benches, not conferring substantive right of appeal.

court_reasoning.text: Garikapati principles apply to substantive right of appeal, not to procedural aspect of bench composition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No right of appeal taken away; merely procedural change.

court_reasoning.text: Cited Ittavira Mathai: no vested right to have appeal heard by specified number of judges; appeal was heard and disposed by HC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Overrule contention based on Radhakishan case.

court_reasoning.text: No vested right to Division Bench means no right to appeal under Art.133 from single Judge decision vests.
Point on maintainability not raised in courts below, declined to entertain.

holdings.text: Appeals rightly heard and decided by single Judge of High Court; no vested right to have appeal heard by Division Bench.
Right to bench composition is procedural, not substantive vested right.
Hearing by single Judge does not infringe right under Art.133 as no vested right to appeal from single Judge exists otherwise.

precedents_cited.relevance: Relied by appellant; held not approved as right to Division Bench is procedural.
Right to Division Bench is procedural, can be taken away retrospectively by implication.

precedents_cited.case_name: Garikapati Veerara v. N. Subbaiah Choudhury
precedents_cited.relevance: Principles on vested right of appeal agreed, but inapplicable as no substantive right taken away.
No vested right to specified number of judges; similar objection raised and rejected.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars appeal to SC from single Judge; does not detract from special leave power; no vested right under Art.133 if heard by single Judge.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin High Court Act 5 of 1125 M.E. (1949 A.D.)
statutes_cited.relevance: Required appeals over Rs.1000 heard by Division Bench; procedural, repealed.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala High Court Act, 1958 (Act 5 of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Extended single Judge jurisdiction to appeals up to Rs.10,000; procedural change applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Source of substantive right to appeal from court of first instance.

statutes_cited.name: Travancore-Cochin Civil Courts Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Relates to subordinate courts; does not confer right of appeal.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, holding that the High Court appeals were rightly heard by a single Judge as bench composition is a procedural matter with no vested right to a Division Bench; declined to interfere with findings of fact absent grave errors and rejected new point on suit maintainability.

key_quotes.text: "No party has a vested right to have his appeal heard by a specified number of judges."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding that bench composition is procedural.

key_quotes.text: "The right of appeal is not a mere matter of procedure but is a substantive right."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes substantive appeal right from procedural bench issue, citing Garikapati.

key_quotes.text: "It is the settled practice of this Court not to interfere with a finding of fact arrived at by the High Court unless it is satisfied that in arriving at the finding of fact the High Court had been guilty of grave errors."
key_quotes.speaker: court
